research_note: RedNote MCP unavailable due to headless browser environment. Research based on knowledge of Chinese city specialties combined with Gaode Maps verification of shopping locations. Prices estimated in EUR based on 2026 exchange rates (1 EUR = 7.8 CNY approx).

payment_methods: Alipay and WeChat Pay essential in mainland China
Hong Kong and Macau more credit card friendly
Keep cash (RMB) for small vendors and markets
Bargaining expected in markets, not modern malls
bargaining_strategy: Traditional markets: Start at 40-50% of asking price
Tourist areas: Prices often 200-300% inflated - bargain hard
Fixed price shops: Department stores, branded shops, museums - no bargaining
Tea and silk: Know market prices before shopping to avoid overpaying
Walk away if price too high - vendors often call you back with better offer
avoiding_scams: Terracotta warriors: Buy from museum shop only, avoid street vendors
Tea shops: Beware 'tea ceremony' scams where you're pressured to buy expensive tea
Jade and jewelry: Very difficult to authenticate - avoid unless expert
Silk: Buy from museum shops or established stores with certificates
Antiques: Assume everything is fake reproduction unless proven otherwise
Taxi to shopping: Beware taxi drivers taking commission - they'll overcharge
packing_tips: Bring extra foldable bag for souvenirs
Fragile items (ceramics, tea sets): Pack in carry-on with clothes as padding
Liquids (XO sauce, wine): Check in luggage, wrap in plastic bags
Tea: Vacuum-sealed packages keep fresh and save space
Weight limit: Check luggage allowance - Chinese souvenirs add up quickly
customs_considerations: Dried fruits: Some countries restrict - check regulations
Dried seafood: Often restricted - verify before buying
Meat products (jerky): Many countries prohibit - research first
Herbal products: May require documentation in some countries
Alcohol: Usually 1-2 liters allowed, check your airline
Tea and silk: Generally no restrictions
when_to_shop: Don't shop first day - you'll find better items/prices later
Buy heavy/fragile items on last day to avoid carrying
Food items: Buy near end of trip for freshness
Tea and silk: Compare prices across multiple cities before buying
Markets: Visit morning for freshest food items, evening for bargains
Avoid major holidays - shops crowded and may have higher prices
budget_allocation_by_trip_length: 2-3 day trip (Suzhou, Hangzhou, Xiamen): 40-70 EUR - moderate souvenirs
3-4 day trip (Xi'an, Guangzhou, Hong Kong): 50-80 EUR - good shopping opportunity
4-5 day trip (Guilin): 40-50 EUR - focus on experiences, light shopping
Tea purchases can significantly increase budget (add 50-100 EUR for quality tea)

best_shopping_cities.reason: Longjing tea - unique local product worth the expense
XO sauce, milk tea products, bakery items - good quality and unique
Silk and embroidery - if interested in textiles
Terracotta replicas, traditional crafts, dried fruits
Almond cookies, pork jerky - good gifts, compact

light_shopping_cities.reason: Focus on nature experience, limited unique shopping
Tourist trap shops, focus on scenery instead
Short trip from Beijing, save luggage space

notes: Shopping budgets are estimates for souvenirs and local specialties per trip. Actual spending varies based on personal preferences. Tea purchases (especially Longjing in Hangzhou) can significantly increase budgets. Hong Kong shopping depends on cosmetics/electronics interests. Focus on compact, lightweight items due to luggage constraints across multiple trips. All prices in EUR based on approximate 2026 exchange rate of 1 EUR = 7.8 CNY.
